summary.html: issue #464

values.description:
Without this change, it gives errors like the following:
~~~
/home/scpeters/bin/bb:33:in `+': can't convert nil into String (TypeError)
	from /home/scpeters/bin/bb:33:in `to_s'
	from /home/scpeters/bin/bb:75:in `block in listPullRequests'
	from /home/scpeters/bin/bb:75:in `each'
	from /home/scpeters/bin/bb:75:in `listPullRequests'
	from /home/scpeters/bin/bb:180:in `<main>'
~~~

Using the -v option, I was able to see that the json data structure had changed ("sha" -> "hash") and make this fix.

UPDATE:
They just changed the API again, so I fixed it again, but who knows what other changes they are going to make. If they make any more breaking changes before this gets merged, I'm going to decline this pull request and keep the fixes in a private branch until things stabilize a bit.
values.title: Fix bitbucket_pullrequests tool, broken by API change (#933)

values.description:
Adds api to set joint effort limits (#923), which could previously only be initialized by sdf parameters.

Targeted to gazebo_2.1, new API function added at end of class to preserve ABI.

[Compatibility report](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/issue_923_compat_report.html)

values.description:
I wrote a test that stresses the creation of a model with a sensor. I discovered that SpawnWirelessTransceiverSensor() and SpawnWireessReceiverSensor() were not waiting for the sensor to be ready. I believe this is the reason of the sporadic transceiver errors that @_jrivero_  was noticing. I fixed with a new function WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

In the meantime I have changed all the SpawnXXXSensor() to use WaitUntilEntitySpawn() and WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

[API/ABI report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/25/consoleText).
values.title: Fix transceiver sporadic errors

summary.raw:
I wrote a test that stresses the creation of a model with a sensor. I discovered that SpawnWirelessTransceiverSensor() and SpawnWireessReceiverSensor() were not waiting for the sensor to be ready. I believe this is the reason of the sporadic transceiver errors that @_jrivero_  was noticing. I fixed with a new function WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

In the meantime I have changed all the SpawnXXXSensor() to use WaitUntilEntitySpawn() and WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

[API/ABI report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/25/consoleText).
summary.html:
I wrote a test that stresses the creation of a model with a sensor. I discovered that SpawnWirelessTransceiverSensor() and SpawnWireessReceiverSensor() were not waiting for the sensor to be ready. I believe this is the reason of the sporadic transceiver errors that @jrivero was noticing. I fixed with a new function WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

In the meantime I have changed all the SpawnXXXSensor() to use WaitUntilEntitySpawn() and WaitUntilSensorSpawn().

API/ABI report.

values.description:
Add DEM support into Gazebo. You can load any raster DEM file, as long as it's supported by GDAL. GDAL will be an optional Gazebo library.

On Ubuntu Saucy, Raring or Quantal:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal-dev libgdal1 python-gdal
```
On Ubuntu Precise:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal1-1.7.0 libgdal1-dev python-gdal
```

It depends on [this sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/67/element-used-by-dem-heightmaps/diff).

**Example world**

The example world loads a heightmap from a GeoTiff file. If the SDF element *<size>* is present, the DEM will be loaded in scaled mode. Scaled mode means that the terrain will be scaled according to the *<size>* values. In non-scaled mode the terrain is loaded using its real dimensions.


```
#!c++

gazebo sdf/worlds/heightmap_dem.world

```

**Test**

Unit test for Dem, and integration test for checking that it's working with the GPS sensor.

**Coverage**

Dem.cc has 100% function coverage and 81% condition coverage.

**Tutorial**

There's a new [DEM tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/3.0/gazebo_dem) for Gazebo 3.0.
values.title: DEM support

**Example world**

The example world loads a heightmap from a GeoTiff file. If the SDF element *<size>* is present, the DEM will be loaded in scaled mode. Scaled mode means that the terrain will be scaled according to the *<size>* values. In non-scaled mode the terrain is loaded using its real dimensions.



**Test**

There's a new [DEM tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/3.0/gazebo_dem) for Gazebo 3.0.

Add DEM support into Gazebo. You can load any raster DEM file, as long as it's supported by GDAL. GDAL will be an optional Gazebo library.

On Ubuntu Saucy, Raring or Quantal:

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal-dev libgdal1 python-gdal

On Ubuntu Precise:

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal1-1.7.0 libgdal1-dev python-gdal

It depends on this sdformat pull request.

Example world

The example world loads a heightmap from a GeoTiff file. If the SDF element <size> is present, the DEM will be loaded in scaled mode. Scaled mode means that the terrain will be scaled according to the <size> values. In non-scaled mode the terrain is loaded using its real dimensions.

gazebo sdf/worlds/heightmap_dem.world

Test

Unit test for Dem, and integration test for checking that it's working with the GPS sensor.

Coverage

Dem.cc has 100% function coverage and 81% condition coverage.

values.description: Occasionally gzclient loads up blank (#681). I was able to reproduce this pretty consistently today. A partial fix is to make the Scene subscriber to `~/response` use latching. Note that this is not a complete fix. @nkoenig is thinking about how to write a test for this.
values.title: Partial fix for #681: occasional blank gzclient

summary.raw: Occasionally gzclient loads up blank (#681). I was able to reproduce this pretty consistently today. A partial fix is to make the Scene subscriber to `~/response` use latching. Note that this is not a complete fix. @nkoenig is thinking about how to write a test for this.
summary.html: Occasionally gzclient loads up blank (#681). I was able to reproduce this pretty consistently today. A partial fix is to make the Scene subscriber to ~/response use latching. Note that this is not a complete fix. @nkoenig is thinking about how to write a test for this.

values.description:
fix issue #930. Interpolate range if vertical/horizontal resolution parameters are specified. 

This feature was previously only available in [gazebo_ros_pkgs' block laser](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/hydro-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_block_laser.cpp). 

Functionality ported to gazebo. Added comments to explain the code, and unit and integration tests.
values.title: Fix ray sensor resolution

summary.raw:
fix issue #930. Interpolate range if vertical/horizontal resolution parameters are specified. 

This feature was previously only available in [gazebo_ros_pkgs' block laser](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/hydro-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_block_laser.cpp). 

Functionality ported to gazebo. Added comments to explain the code, and unit and integration tests.

values.description:
Now that libccd packages are in [its own PPA](https://launchpad.net/~libccd-debs) and we probably will copy them to OSRF repo, seems a good moment to make some cleaning in the deps directory.

* Make libccd a needed dependency of gazebo (SearchForStuff.cmake)
* Remove ann, fcl and quickstep since I was not able to find any reference using them in our code base.
values.title: Clean up deps: use external libccd. Remove ann, fcl and quickstep (->default)

summary.raw:
Now that libccd packages are in [its own PPA](https://launchpad.net/~libccd-debs) and we probably will copy them to OSRF repo, seems a good moment to make some cleaning in the deps directory.

* Make libccd a needed dependency of gazebo (SearchForStuff.cmake)
* Remove ann, fcl and quickstep since I was not able to find any reference using them in our code base.
summary.html:
Now that libccd packages are in its own PPA and we probably will copy them to OSRF repo, seems a good moment to make some cleaning in the deps directory.

  • Make libccd a needed dependency of gazebo (SearchForStuff.cmake)
  • Remove ann, fcl and quickstep since I was not able to find any reference using them in our code base.

values.description:
Make it easier to shutdown Gazebo with a single Ctrl-C.

The main change here is to move installation of the SIGINT handler to happen after initialization, just before we're ready to run (in both the server and the client).  A Ctrl-C delivered in the meantime will cause immediate program exit (default behavior for SIGINT).  As far as I can tell, that should be OK, and it gets rid of the most common hang-on-shutdown conditions, which happen when the user tries to exit after something has gone wrong (or taken too long) during initialization.

I also improved the process monitor in gazebo_main.cc.

And I removed some dead files that I found distracting.
values.title: Clean up shutdown (#441)

summary.raw:
Make it easier to shutdown Gazebo with a single Ctrl-C.

The main change here is to move installation of the SIGINT handler to happen after initialization, just before we're ready to run (in both the server and the client).  A Ctrl-C delivered in the meantime will cause immediate program exit (default behavior for SIGINT).  As far as I can tell, that should be OK, and it gets rid of the most common hang-on-shutdown conditions, which happen when the user tries to exit after something has gone wrong (or taken too long) during initialization.

I also improved the process monitor in gazebo_main.cc.

And I removed some dead files that I found distracting.
summary.html:
Make it easier to shutdown Gazebo with a single Ctrl-C.

The main change here is to move installation of the SIGINT handler to happen after initialization, just before we're ready to run (in both the server and the client). A Ctrl-C delivered in the meantime will cause immediate program exit (default behavior for SIGINT). As far as I can tell, that should be OK, and it gets rid of the most common hang-on-shutdown conditions, which happen when the user tries to exit after something has gone wrong (or taken too long) during initialization.

I also improved the process monitor in gazebo_main.cc.

And I removed some dead files that I found distracting.

values.description:
This is another part of improving command line tools to control aspects of gazebo.

This pull request creates a camera command message, that can move a simulated camera.

A forthcoming pull request will provide a command line tool that uses this capability.

values.description:
It depends on [this Gazebo_models pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/66/models-for-the-robocup-spl-environment/diff).

* New colors:

    *SkyBlue*: Used in one of the RoboCup09 goals.

    *ZincYellow*: Used in the RoboCup goals nowadays.

    *RedBright*: Used in the RoboCup ball.
    
    Note: The blue and yellow colors are normalized [RAL colors](http://www.ralcolor.com/).

* New textures:

    *Net*: Used in the goals.
  
    *Carpet*: Used in the RoboCup fields.

* New world files:

    *robocup09_spl_field*: Used for image validation and old school RoboCupers

    *robocup14_spl_field*: Current environment.

I've fixed the indentation in the materials file.

For testing:

```
#!c++

gazebo sdf/worlds/robocup09_spl_field.world

```

```
#!c++

gazebo sdf/worlds/robocup14_spl_field.world

```
values.title: Colors, textures and world files for the SPL RoboCup environment

values.description:
Inserting a pr2 into a world with bullet causes a console spam from BulletScrewJoint::SetForce. This converts that message to gzlog so the console is not spammed.

This line also comprises a significant fraction of some of our [Jenkins logs](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_2.1-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/13/console).
values.title: Make bullet quieter with PR2

summary.raw:
Inserting a pr2 into a world with bullet causes a console spam from BulletScrewJoint::SetForce. This converts that message to gzlog so the console is not spammed.

This line also comprises a significant fraction of some of our [Jenkins logs](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_2.1-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/13/console).
summary.html:
Inserting a pr2 into a world with bullet causes a console spam from BulletScrewJoint::SetForce. This converts that message to gzlog so the console is not spammed.

This line also comprises a significant fraction of some of our Jenkins logs.

values.title: Remove cppcheck warnings.

summary.raw:

```
#!c++
```

values.title: Re-fix #933, bitbucket_pullrequests tool

summary.html:
The bitbucket pull request API has been released. This pull request fixes the last breakages (/patch replaced with /diff, #933) and adds a few features.

$ bitbucket_pullrequests -h
Usage: bitbucket_pullrequests [options]
    -l, --list                       List open pull requests with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -c, --check [id]
    -d, --diff [id]                  Show diff from pull request
    -f, --files [id]                 Show changed files in a pull request
    -s, --summary [id]               Summarize a pull request with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -u, --show-url                   Show urls accessed
    -v, --verbose                    Verbose output
    -h, --help                       Display this help message

New features:

  • -d, --diff: Print a diff for the pull request
  • -u, --url: Print the urls accessed by the tool
  • -v, --verbose: Print the raw JSON received from bitbucket
# --diff
$ ./bitbucket_pullrequests --diff 840
diff -r c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0 -r 0676064f7ae2ef9e6c7416e6b0b244a372cc954f test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc
--- a/test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc
+++ b/test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc
@@ -61,11 +61,8 @@
   }

   // get two cameras, one with rotation and one without.
-  std::string modelUnrotated = "cam_x_rot_test_unrotated_cameras_1";
   std::string cameraUnrotated = "multicamera_sensor_unrotated";
-  std::string modelRotated1 = "cam_x_rot_test_rotated_cameras_1";
   std::string cameraRotated1 = "multicamera_sensor_rotated1";
-  std::string modelRotated2 = "cam_x_rot_test_rotated_cameras_2";
   std::string cameraRotated2 = "multicamera_sensor_rotated2";

   sensors::SensorPtr sensor = sensors::get_sensor(cameraUnrotated);

# --url
$ ./bitbucket_pullrequests --url -s 840
https://bitbucket.org/api/2.0/repositories/osrf/gazebo/pullrequests/840
  840    e072b20a8684    c5b1d48b8aee    fix_cppcheck_warnings

# --verbose
$ ./bitbucket_pullrequests --verbose -s 840
{
  "description": "\r\n```\r\n#!c++\r\n\r\n[test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc:64]: (style) Variable 'modelUnrotated' is assigned a value that is never used\r\n[test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc:66]: (style) Variable 'modelRotated1' is assigned a value that is never used\r\n[test/integration/multicamera_sensor.cc:68]: (style) Variable 'modelRotated2' is assigned a value that is never used\r\nTotal errors found: 0\r\n```\r\n",
  "links": {
    "decline": {
      "href": "https://bitbucket.org/api/2.0/repositories/osrf/gazebo/pullrequests/840/decline"
    },
...
    "approve": {
      "href": "https://bitbucket.org/api/2.0/repositories/osrf/gazebo/pullrequests/840/approve"
    }
  },
  "title": "Remove cppcheck warnings.",
  "close_source_branch": true,
  "reviewers": [

  ],
  "destination": {
    "commit": {
      "hash": "c5b1d48b8aee",
      "links": {
        "self": {
          "href": "https://bitbucket.org/api/2.0/repositories/osrf/gazebo/commit/c5b1d48b8aee"

values.description:
Currently several files are recompiled for every test. This pull request creates a static library and links to each test to reduce compilation time. Even with ccache, it still reduces build time by 9%. I have another pull request in the pipeline that will reduce build time by 30% (even with ccache) when tests are enabled; this is just part 1.

UPDATE: I added another piece to this, which moves code from ServerFixture.hh to ServerFixture.cc. I tried to minimize changes to the code. This gives an additional 10% speed-up for me (about 20% total).

UPDATE: Found a cmake bug, in which cmake would re-link if libserver_fixture.a changed. I linked to the absolute path of the library in ae05a9c and that fixed it.
values.title: Speed up test compilation (part of #955)

UPDATE: I added another piece to this, which moves code from ServerFixture.hh to ServerFixture.cc. I tried to minimize changes to the code. This gives an additional 10% speed-up for me (about 20% total).

UPDATE: Found a cmake bug, in which cmake would re-link if libserver_fixture.a changed. I linked to the absolute path of the library in ae05a9c and that fixed it.

Even with ccache, it still reduces build time by 9%. I have another pull request in the pipeline that will reduce build time by 30% (even with ccache) when tests are enabled; this is just part 1.

values.description:
This pull request adds support for the [DART physics engine](http://dartsim.github.io/). Thanks to @jlee02 @karenliu @\_jrivero_ and Tobias Kunz for their work to support this.

In order to install dart, please add the libccd-debs, fcl-debs, and dartsim PPA's to your apt sources and install libdart-core3-dev:
~~~
sudo apt-add repository ppa:libccd-debs
sudo apt-add repository ppa:fcl-debs
sudo apt-add repository ppa:dartsim
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libdart-core3-dev
~~~
These debs are available for precise, quantal, and raring. There is a problem with saucy that is being worked on.

This pull request targets gazebo_2.1, and I expect ABI to be compatible. To make sure, I just started an [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/34/)) on Jenkins.

There are a number of places where DART doesn't pass integration tests. In these cases, issues have been created, and conditionals added to the test files. Search the issue tracker for component [physics::DARTPhysics](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues?component=physics::DARTPhysics) to see the full list.

I have not personally reviewed all the code in the gazebo/physics/dart subfolder, but I have tried to make sure the build is clean (no warnings, code_check errors, or test failures).

UPDATE: retargeted to gazebo_2.2 branch

In order to install dart, please add the libccd-debs, fcl-debs, and dartsim PPA's to your apt sources and install libdart-core3-dev:
~~~
sudo apt-add repository ppa:libccd-debs

These debs are available for precise, quantal, and raring. There is a problem with saucy that is being worked on.

This pull request targets gazebo_2.1, and I expect ABI to be compatible. To make sure, I just started an [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/34/)) on Jenkins.

There are a number of places where DART doesn't pass integration tests. In these cases, issues have been created, and conditionals added to the test files. Search the issue tracker for component [physics::DARTPhysics](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues?component=physics::DARTPhysics) to see the full list.

summary.html:
This pull request adds support for the DART physics engine. Thanks to @jlee02 @karenliu @_jrivero_ and Tobias Kunz for their work to support this.

In order to install dart, please add the libccd-debs, fcl-debs, and dartsim PPA's to your apt sources and install libdart-core3-dev:

sudo apt-add repository ppa:libccd-debs
sudo apt-add repository ppa:fcl-debs
sudo apt-add repository ppa:dartsim
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libdart-core3-dev

These debs are available for precise, quantal, and raring. There is a problem with saucy that is being worked on.

This pull request targets gazebo_2.1, and I expect ABI to be compatible. To make sure, I just started an ABI checker) on Jenkins.

There are a number of places where DART doesn't pass integration tests. In these cases, issues have been created, and conditionals added to the test files. Search the issue tracker for component physics::DARTPhysics to see the full list.

I have not personally reviewed all the code in the gazebo/physics/dart subfolder, but I have tried to make sure the build is clean (no warnings, code_check errors, or test failures).

UPDATE: retargeted to gazebo_2.2 branch
